reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars What Can I Say? It's George R R Martin!
reviews.reviewText: Not only is this part of the best fantasy series I've ever read, but it is my favorite related saga - the tales of Dunk and Egg. Very nicely illustrated in pen and ink (I favor pen and ink drawings for books) and the stories are a great read. I've read them twice now, and I am sure that in another year or two I will want to read them again. The product quality was good, and Amazon is a pro at shipping books so that they arrive in good condition.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I love Dunk the Lunk thick as a castle wall
reviews.reviewText: [ 5 of 5 stars ]The Mystery Knight: A Graphic Novel (The Tales of Dunk and Egg, #3)by Ben AveryOne of the reasons I liked Dunk the Lunk was his open innocence. He was working on going north only to find a big problem. His innocence causes him problems as he tries at a tilt. He looses his equipment to ransom because of his inability to handle the lance as well as he does his sword. The political world the seven kingdoms has so many real world parallels. Showing George's obsession with history. I love how he brings the world of Westeros to his audience in so many mediums. The comic book is a great medium for his stories.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another Astonishing Great Adaptation
reviews.reviewText: The graphic novel adaptation of the third of George R.R. Martin’s Dunk & Egg novellas not only stays true to the original story while also giving it a new dimension with fantastic renderings of all the characters, the locales, and the action. Drawn by artist Mike S. Miller based on the adaptation by Ben Avery, The Mystery Knight immediately builds upon the previous adventure of Ser Duncan (Dunk) the Tall and the future Aegon (Egg) V as they stumble upon conspiracy from an enemy from across the sea.Avery adaptation and Miller’s art effectively brings the novella to life though to be honest some of the character designs while not off-putting or interesting, particularly a character that is attempting to kill Dunk due to jealousy. The appearance of the often-mentioned Lord Bloodraven is particularly amazing, not only the character’s artwork but the double page appearance with him front and center. There was a small change in the order of the story, but it worked well in the flow of the graphic novel and didn’t affect the overall work. The graphic novel adaptation of The Mystery Knight is something every A Song of Ice and Fire fan should get their hands on.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Story Adaptation, Technical Kindle Problems
reviews.reviewText: CAVEAT: This is a Kindle Edition Review, which considers the story and the medium with separate standards.Story: This is a graphic adaptation of the GRRM short story "The Mystery Knight," which builds more backstory into "A Song of Ice and Fire." If you're new to the series, you should start with "The Hedge Knight."In this story, Ser Duncan the Tall and his squire Egg are making their way north across the Riverlands when they decide to join the festivities of wealthy Lord Butterwell's wedding. There will be a feast and a jousting tourney, with Lord Butterwell's dragon egg as the prize. Duncan tries out some privileges of knighthood for himself and finds them a mixed bag, just as his old master Ser Arlan warned him. Egg, with his eye for social subtleties, senses the political elephant in the castle before Duncan. The knights, the lordly Houses and the exercise of power and symbolism are all themes we get another perspective on, building on the work of "The Hedge Knight," "The Sworn Sword," and other ASOIAF titles.My only quibble with the story, as told, is two lines lost in translation from the short story. At the campfire by the lake, after Ser Kyle tells the salacious story of where Butterwell's dragon egg came from, Dunc makes the quip that "If half those old stories were true, we'd all be bastard sons of old King Aegon." Ser Maynard Plumm ripostes "Who says we aren't?!"Medium: Like Adam Charlton notes in his review, many panels could stand some more zoom. You can't magnify the text or the action and read these beautiful panels like you can in the Kindle GN edition of "The Hedge Knight," "The Sworn Sword," or "Meathouse Man," other GRRM graphic adaptions I own. 3 screenshots are attached I hope that if the novel is reformatted, kindle owners will be alerted.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another great read from Ser George RR Martin
reviews.reviewText: I love this shorter stories and this graphic novel does not disappoint ASOIF fans.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Old gen Got
reviews.reviewText: Great work, seeing the plots and conspiracy of a generation before the main books and how the “game of thrones” was a volatile in the last as it is in the more recent timeline.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A story of courage, honor, valor and Eggs
reviews.reviewText: This is a great read. I have come to enjoy these stories of Dunk and Egg ; they have adventure, challenges,even blood but somehow a lighter pen and an innocence which is refreshing inbetween the heaviness which is GoT. The art is wonderful. I have two little beefs: no women in the story..is that the reason men chose to play chicken with horses, metal football padding and long sticks?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great Art for a Great Story
reviews.reviewText: The Dunk & Egg novellas are excellent. If you're a fan of GRRM's ASOIF universe, they are a must-read. This graphic novel is a wonderful depiction of the (so far) final novella in the Dunk & Egg storyline.
I absolutely love my graphic novels! The detail is outstanding!Very beautiful art work! Highly recommend to Game Of Thrones lovers

della scombinata coppia fatta dal cavaliere senza denari e dal suo fido scudiero Egg testa pelata - principe in incognito. Prequel della storia principale de Il Trono di Spade si legge molto volentieri se siete appassionati al genere. Versione kindle in lingua originale in offerta. Che altro ?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 8, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: a visual feast with a good story
reviews.reviewText: As a fan of graphic novels in general and being a fan of George R.R Martin and owning the 4 volumes of the Game of Thrones graphic novels and of the orginal novels this is a great addition to any one of other fans of either graphic novels or any fans of this particular author, the art work is flawless as is the concept all in all a very good read, gone are the days that comic books or graphic novels were just for kids they have now evolved in to something else entirely with something like this it is basiclly just like seeing a film but on paper when youb think about it it is visual and with words just like a film on tv is really instead of the actors speaking the words on screen with this you have the same effect only you have the visual effects but with the actors speaking to you of the page basiclly a script but with pictures.
Papel de calidad, muy buen diseño y una historia simplemente genial (a la altura de la primera) que encantará a todos los fans.

In marked contrast to the ASOIAF comics (A Game of Thrones, A Clash of Kings) which are kind of rubbish, the series on the Hedge Knight really delivers, and this one is no exception. If you liked the previous ones, you should get this. If you don't, don't buy it, you won't like this one either. If you don't know the first two, get them first, or you'll not understand anything.
